text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES

IRM 1.33.1, Program Scope and Objectives, added to conform to the new internal control requirements described in IRM 1.11.2, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process. Also, rearranged and updated existing IRM content to place information involving internal controls for the IRM under this subsection. All other subsequent subsections were renumbered accordingly

IRM 1.33.3, Reimbursable Operating Guidelines, was revised to remove all references to transactions and forms no longer supported by the updated version of the Integrated Financial System (IFS) and to include updated reimbursable processes.
IRM 1.33.3.4, Agreements, revised to include the updated reimbursable approval process.

IRM 1.33.3.6, Budget and Accounting Procedures, revised to remove transactions and accounting codes no longer in use under IFS and to update the change in budget versions and the reimbursable processes.

Included numerous editorial changes and updates throughout, including organizational name change from Agency-Wide Shared Services (AWSS) to Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS), terminology changes and title updates to division ﬁnance officers and ﬁnancial plan managers.
Included numerous editorial changes and updates throughout, including organizational name from Beckley Finance Center (BFC) to Government Payables (GP) and Funds Management (FM)
AUDIENCE

The IRS budget community in all ﬁnance offices, especially employees responsible for the administrative control of funds related to reimbursable business with federal and non-federal entities. This includes, but is limited to, division ﬁnance officers (DFOs), ﬁnancial plan managers (FPMs) and their staff involved in establishing, costing, and approving agreements, and accounting, billing, and collecting reimbursable funds owed to the IRS.
Table of Contents

) Purpose: The Reimbursable Operating Guidelines (ROG) are internal funds control guidance developed to assist division ﬁnance officers (DFOs), plan managers (FPMs) and related staffs with establishing, costing, and approving agreements and with accounting, billing and collecting funds owed to the IRS. (

) Audience: The IRS budget community in all ﬁnance offices, especially employees responsible for the administrative control of funds related to reim- bursable business with federal and non-federal entities. (
) Policy Owner: The CFO’s Corporate Budget (CB) office is responsible for policy decisions reﬂected in the ROG. (

) Program Owner: The ROG is published by Corporate Budget. Comments change requests may be submitted to the director, Budget Execution Office. Future revisions, including interim guidance, will be posted to the Corporate Budget website. (
) Primary Stakeholders: All IRS management, especially the IRS budget community in all divisions. (

) Program Goals: To assist all FPMs and other budget and ﬁnance involved in establishing, costing, and approving agreements and accounting, billing and collecting reimbursable funds owed to the IRS. The IRM is not speciﬁc to ﬁscal year (FY) and is in effect until superseded. These take precedence over any previous reimbursable operating instructions.

Program Goals: To assist all FPMs and other budget and ﬁnance professionals involved in establishing, costing, and approving agreements and accounting, billing and collecting reimbursable funds owed to the IRS. The IRM is not speciﬁc to ﬁscal year (FY) and is in effect until superseded. These guidelines take precedence over any previous reimbursable operating instructions.
Note: In the event of a Continuing Resolution (CR), any guidance speciﬁc to the CR will be posted on the
Corporate Budget website and will supersede this IRM, where applicable. (
) The Antideﬁciency Act requires all government agencies to prescribe, by lation, a funds control system. The funds control system is intended to

) restrict both obligations and expenditures from each appropriation or fund account to the lower of the amount apportioned by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) or the amount available in the appropriation or fund account and to
) enable the agency head to identify the person(s) for exceeding appropriations, apportionments, allotments, statutory limitations or other administrative subdivisions of funds. (
) This guidance provides funds control regulations, as required by OMB A-
, Preparation, Submission and Execution of the Budget, Part
, Section
, Administrative control of funds. (

) This IRM addresses funds-in reimbursable activity where the IRS functions as the seller of reimbursable goods and/or services. These guidelines do not apply to funds-out agreements where the IRS serves as the buyer procuring services from other governmental and nongovernmental entities. (
) This IRM provides useful contact information and addresses that are to DFOs, budget directors, FPMs, and related staffs. The ROG standardizes agreements, billing, and collections.
Corporate Budget website and will supersede this IRM, where applicable.
Strategic Planning, Budgeting and Performance Management Process
IRM provides accounting guidance for recording and transferring between the Integrated Financial System (IFS) direct and reimburs- fund accounts.
The director, Budget Execution, is responsible for: a. Providing budgetary oversight, accountability, legal and overall manage

ment responsibility for the IRS reimbursable program. b. Approving and issuing IRS ﬁnancial management guidance governing the reimbursable program. c. Ensuring the IRS does not violate the Antideﬁciency Act at the agency level. To meet the IRS’s collective ﬁnancial management responsibilities, the director, Budget Execution relies on the DFOs for compliance with the law and guidelines. d. Responding to Treasury, OMB and audit organizations on IRS reimburs

able budget and agreement structure issues. e. Serving as the Servicewide reimbursables coordinator by developing and implementing IRS administrative policies and procedures governing the reimbursable program, such as this IRM, call memos for projected spend plans and year
end procedures. f. Preparing budget estimates, inputs and reports intended for external audiences. g. Preparing, submitting and monitoring apportionments for all reimbursable projects.
Operating Guidelines 1.33.3

Creating and coordinating IFS funded program codes for new able projects. Ensuring the reimbursable appropriation is distributed from the tion level to the authority level. Entering forecasts of revenue and distributing budget and full

time lents (FTE) to the authority level. Responding to ﬁnancial control issues. Providing reimbursable oversight of business units. Monitoring and analyzing IRS reimbursable projects for system errors earnings progress. Monitoring and supporting year

end close activities. Coordinating with the Cost Accounting and User Fees office on overhead cost policy and methodology. Reviewing and approving (by signing and dating) business unit able agreements, cost estimates and overhead cost estimates. Maintaining a copy of the ﬁnal agreement with all appropriate signatures once a forecast of revenue is input. Determining whether a reimbursable agreement needs to be reviewed by the Financial Reporting office and ensuring the agreement is made to them.
The director, Cost Accounting and User Fees, is responsible for:
a. Developing a reimbursable overhead rate and methodology. b. Establishing and maintaining the IRS cost accounting policies and proce
dures. c. Providing advice and assistance to FPMs, reimbursable project coordina
tors (RPCs), and budget office reimbursable coordinators (BORCs) on the costing of respective reimbursable projects.
a. Monitoring, reviewing and analyzing reimbursable activity for IRS ﬁnancial statement reports and general ledger accounts. b. Providing guidance on reimbursable ﬁnancial reporting matters, as appro

priate, through its Corporate Budget and Governments Payable and Funds Management counterparts. c. Reviewing and approving any agreements identiﬁed by Corporate Budget that require other than monthly billing arrangements.
Strategic Planning, Budgeting and Performance Management Process
Strategic Planning, Budgeting and Management Process (

) The director, Government Payables and Funds Management, is responsible for: a. Ensuring that reimbursable agreements are recorded properly in the ministrative ﬁnancial statements and accounting systems. b. Verifying that all required parties have signed a ratiﬁed reimbursable agreement and are maintaining appropriate documentation to support billing, such as agreement documentation. c. Coordinating billing requirements between IRS and its reimbursable buyers. d. Collecting, posting and monitoring reimbursable earnings and in IFS. e. Informing the Servicewide reimbursables team and the budget office imbursable coordinator (BORC) when advance payments are received. f. Ensuring each agreement contains a valid master data customer The Government Payables Section will complete a customer code form for business units and submit it to the Obligations Office when customer codes are required. (

) Business units are responsible for the ﬁnancial management and funds of their respective reimbursable agreements and project accounting require- ments. It is recommended that each business unit establish three administrative levels to carry out the proper execution and ﬁnancial control reimbursable agreements. These levels and associated responsibilities are: a. RPC b. BORC c. FPM/funding official (

) The RPC is responsible for: a. Ensuring agreement terms and conditions comply with appropriations principles and are negotiated, ﬁnalized and signed by all required b. Coordinating with the BORC in developing accurate project cost estimates (including both direct and indirect costs) and ensuring cost rates are accurate and up-to-date. c. Coordinating with the BORC on securing all necessary approvals and signatures for the reimbursable agreement, including from Corporate Budget. d. Coordinating with the BORC on accounting for reimbursable costs, amounts, and reimbursable earnings. e. Negotiating the agreement with the buyer. If the buyer does not agree the cost estimates, the RPC should contact the IRS reimbursables for support. f. Ensuring a binding agreement is authorized between the IRS, as the seller, and the customer, as the buyer before reimbursable work begins. g. Providing a copy of the signed agreement to the BORC. h. Maintaining documentation on statutory authorities, apportionments, contracts, legal opinions and other substantiating materials. i. Maintaining a ﬁnal copy of the signed reimbursable agreement, cost calculations and supporting documentation or basis for to the agreement. j. Processing earnings transactions promptly.
The director, Government Payables and Funds Management, is responsible
a. Ensuring that reimbursable agreements are recorded properly in the ad

ministrative ﬁnancial statements and accounting systems. b. Verifying that all required parties have signed a ratiﬁed reimbursable agreement and are maintaining appropriate documentation to support billing, such as agreement documentation. c. Coordinating billing requirements between IRS and its reimbursable buyers. d. Collecting, posting and monitoring reimbursable earnings and payments in IFS. e. Informing the Servicewide reimbursables team and the budget office re

imbursable coordinator (BORC) when advance payments are received. f. Ensuring each agreement contains a valid master data customer The Government Payables Section will complete a customer code form for business units and submit it to the Obligations Office when new customer codes are required.

a. RPC b. BORC c. FPM/funding official The RPC is responsible for: a. Ensuring agreement terms and conditions comply with appropriations principles and are negotiated, ﬁnalized and signed by all required b. Coordinating with the BORC in developing accurate project cost estimates (including both direct and indirect costs) and ensuring cost rates are accurate and up
to

date. c. Coordinating with the BORC on securing all necessary approvals and signatures for the reimbursable agreement, including from Corporate Budget. d. Coordinating with the BORC on accounting for reimbursable costs, amounts, and reimbursable earnings. e. Negotiating the agreement with the buyer. If the buyer does not agree the cost estimates, the RPC should contact the IRS reimbursables for support. f. Ensuring a binding agreement is authorized between the IRS, as the seller, and the customer, as the buyer before reimbursable work begins. g. Providing a copy of the signed agreement to the BORC. h. Maintaining documentation on statutory authorities, apportionments, contracts, legal opinions and other substantiating materials. i. Maintaining a ﬁnal copy of the signed reimbursable agreement, cost calculations and supporting documentation or basis for to the agreement. j. Processing earnings transactions promptly.
Operating Guidelines 1.33.3

Using IFS reports and analysis tools to identify and promptly address counting errors and misalignments during the ﬁscal year. Alerting the BORC to instances when more budget authority may be needed. Establishing advance plans and closing out reimbursable projects in a timely manner.

counting errors and misalignments during the ﬁscal year. l. Alerting the BORC to instances when more budget authority may be needed. m. Establishing advance plans and closing out reimbursable projects in a timely manner. (

) The BORC is responsible for: a. Coordinating with the RPC in reviewing and evaluating project cost estimates for accuracy, implementing adjustments, as necessary, and resolving accounting issues. b. Sending reimbursable direct, indirect and overhead cost estimates to Corporate Budget for approval. c. Requesting funded program numbers for new reimbursable projects by email. d. Providing a copy of the ﬁnal, signed reimbursable agreement to Corporate Budget and Government Payables Section. e. Developing and providing forecast of revenue and budget estimate documents to Corporate Budget in the requested format. f. Promptly parking accurate earnings in IFS according to the method of billing. g. Maintaining appropriate ﬁnancial oversight of reimbursable earnings ensuring collections are received according to the billing and payment frequency set in the agreement. h. Monitoring earnings to assess whether intervention is needed to earnings postings that fall below projections. i. Monitoring FTE alignment. j. Notifying the RPC of changes to the agreement amount and providing a copy of the updated reimbursable agreement for increases. k. Obtaining signatures from all parties, including Corporate Budget, for agreements with estimates that have increased. For agreements where projections need to be reduced, agreements do not need to be signed again. l. Alerting Corporate Budget to the need for more budget authority and providing accurate estimates and explanations for the additional budget authority needed. m. Coordinating with and providing support to CFO on the year-end of reimbursable projects. (

) The FPM/funding official is responsible for: a. Ensuring proper ﬁnancial oversight of business unit’s reimbursable ments. b. In situations where it is not feasible to have three different people perform these three jobs, one person may be both the RPC and the BORC. The FPM role must always be carried out by someone who is neither the RPC nor the BORC. (

) Program reports: Corporate Budget monitors ﬁnancial plans monthly and through more comprehensive reviews of reports using IFS reports and including the status of available funds report and weekly reimbursables FPM responsibilities include using IFS to identify surpluses or deﬁcits early, that the IRS can optimize resource use. Internal Revenue Manual

Program reports: Corporate Budget monitors ﬁnancial plans monthly and through more comprehensive reviews of reports using IFS reports and queries, including the status of available funds report and weekly reimbursables report. FPM responsibilities include using IFS to identify surpluses or deﬁcits early, so
Strategic Planning, Budgeting and Management Process (

) Program effectiveness: To monitor and manage IRS resources, business participate in several Corporate Budget ﬁnancial reviews throughout the year, including the midyear/spend plan review and other formal reviews described IRM
, Financial Accounting Annual Close Guidelines. (

) IFS reports, such as the status of available funds and status of availability control reports, are available for DFOs and FPMs to monitor funds. DFOs their staffs should be familiar with the features of these reports and run them regularly to monitor the funds for which they are responsible. Note: Servicewide availability controls keep the IRS from over-obligating at the fund level. Each business unit also has customized availability controls for ﬁnancial plan at a chosen master data element or combination of master data elements, including fund, fund center, functional area, commitment and funded program. (

) IFS is the system of record that Corporate Budget, DFOs and FPMs must to manage budgetary resources effectively. IFS includes availability controls help prevent the IRS from exceeding its budget authority. Therefore, the and FPMs must review overall funds availability before the posting of to ensure obligated balances will not result in negative availability. (
) IFS security measures, such as control of user roles, are described in IRM
, Financial Accounting, Integrated Financial System Security. (

) The following terms and deﬁnitions apply to this program: a. Advance payment – A pre-payment by the buyer for the later receipt of reimbursable goods and/or services to be provided by the IRS. payments are required for non-federal buyers. b. Agreement period (period of performance) – The time when the IRS incurring costs and/or providing services. This agreement period can be up to one year but may not extend past September

of the ﬁscal year of the agreement unless multi-year funds are available from the buyer the service involves direct charge reimbursable funds, which can be initiated in the funding year and extend past September
c. Agency Location Code (ALC) – Also referred to as the accounting station symbol, is used to identify each federal agency that prepares a FMS

, Statement of Transactions. Treasury uses the ALC to by account symbol its monthly deposits and disbursements by tion, fund and receipts. BORCs must include the ALC on all correspondence, forms and other documentation forwarded to ﬁnancial institutions, the Bureau of Fiscal Service (BFS), and other federal agencies. The IRS ALC requested on Form
A, IAA General Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section; Form
B, IAA Order Requirements and Funding Information (Order) Section; and Form

, Agreement Covering Reimbursable Services With Non-Federal Entities is d. Apportionment – A distribution made by OMB of amounts available for obligation in an appropriation or fund account into amounts available for speciﬁed periods, programs, activities, projects, objects or any tions of these. The apportioned amount limits the obligations that may

security measures, such as control of user roles, are described in IRM Financial Accounting, Integrated Financial System Security.

The following terms and deﬁnitions apply to this program: a. Advance payment – A pre-payment by the buyer for the later receipt of reimbursable goods and/or services to be provided by the IRS. Advance payments are required for non-federal buyers. b. Agreement period (period of performance) – The time when the IRS is incurring costs and/or providing services. This agreement period can be up to one year but may not extend past September

of the ﬁscal year of the agreement unless multi-year funds are available from the buyer or the service involves direct charge reimbursable funds, which can be initiated in the funding year and extend past September
c. Agency Location Code (ALC) – Also referred to as the accounting station symbol, is used to identify each federal agency that prepares a FMS

, Statement of Transactions. Treasury uses the ALC to reconcile by account symbol its monthly deposits and disbursements by appropria- tion, fund and receipts. BORCs must include the ALC on all correspondence, forms and other documentation forwarded to ﬁnancial institutions, the Bureau of Fiscal Service (BFS), and other federal agencies. The IRS ALC requested on Form
A, IAA General Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section; Form
B, IAA Order Requirements and Funding Information (Order) Section; and Form
, Agreement Covering Reimbursable Services With Non-Federal Entities is

d. Apportionment – A distribution made by OMB of amounts available for obligation in an appropriation or fund account into amounts available for speciﬁed periods, programs, activities, projects, objects or any combina- tions of these. The apportioned amount limits the obligations that may be
Guidelines

page incurred. An apportionment may be further subdivided by an agency into allotments, sub-allotments and allocations. e. Bona ﬁde needs rule – The principle that appropriations made for a deﬁnite period of time may be used only for expenses properly incurred during that time. Title
USC Section

(a) (the bona ﬁde needs statute) provides: “The balance of an appropriation or fund limited for ligation to a deﬁnite period is available only for payment of expenses properly incurred during the period of availability or to complete properly made within that period of availability and obligated consistent with Section

of this title. However, the appropriation or fund is not available for expenditure for a period beyond the period otherwise rized by law.” f. Business Event Type Code (BETC) – A four- to eight-character code used in the Governmentwide Accounting (GWA) System to indicate the type of activity being reported, such as payments, collections, disburse- ments, or adjustments. This code must accompany the Treasury Account Symbol (TAS) and the dollar amounts in order to classify the transaction against the fund balance with Treasury. The BETC replaces the transac- tion codes and standard subclasses that were previously used on the central accounting reports, such as those used on the statements of transactions (FMS
). The IRS BETC requested under the Agreement Covering Reimbursable Services on Form
A, IAA General Terms Conditions (GT&C) Section; Form
B, IAA Order Requirements and Funding Information (Order) Section; and Form

, Agreement Covering Reimbursable Services With Non-Federal Entities, is always COLL. g. Business Partner Network (BPN) – The single source for vendor data for the U.S. federal government. The network is used by the government to identify trading partners at a level in an agency where reimbursable business is being conducted. The BPN number indicates the speciﬁc within an agency that is requesting the goods and services. The BPN number is the standard name for this data element, which may be the trading partner’s Data Universal Numbering System number or the De- partment of Defense Activity Address Code (D
AAC). In most cases, the IRS BPN number requested on Form
A, IAA General Terms Conditions (GT&C) Section Form
B, IAA Order Requirements and Funding Information (Order) Section and Form
, Agreement ing Reimbursable Services With Non-Federal Entities) is

, but there may be exceptions. h. Buyer – A trading partner that is purchasing goods and/or services. The buyer, which is also known as the customer, requests services from the IRS. i. Collection – Money collected by the federal government and recorded a receipt, an offsetting collection or an offsetting receipt. j. Commitment – An administrative reservation of funds prior to obligation of funds. Typically, commitments are created by a purchase requisition or shopping cart. k. Commitment item – A subdivision of expense used to classify the zation’s consumption of resources. The ﬁrst two digits of the four-digit represent the higher-level object class. l. Continuing resolution (CR) – A provision of law that authorizes ongoing agency programs to function at previous ﬁscal year funding levels (or levels speciﬁcally stipulated by Congress), under the same terms and con- ditions, for a speciﬁc period. The duration of a CR can vary from a few
Operating Guidelines 1.33.3

Strategic Planning, Budgeting and Management Process days to a full ﬁscal year. When the IRS is under a CR, Corporate Budget publishes special CR operating procedures on the Corporate Budget web- site m. Cost center – A data element in IFS that represents a clearly-deﬁned cation where costs incur and represents the lowest level in the organiza- tional hierarchy, below the fund center. Cost center captures costs only, not revenue. Cost centers are usually linked to speciﬁc managers and their employees but can also be established for non-labor areas, such buildings. n. Direct-Charge Reimbursable Fund Agreements – An agreement amounts are obligated, expenditures incurred, amounts paid, and is recognized directly in the associated direct-charge reimbursable fund. Expenditures initially recorded and paid in a direct fund or direct-charge reimbursable fund may be transferred to or from each other based upon the individual program’s procedures. As of the date of publication, this of agreement only applies to the Treasury Executive Office of Asset ture (TEOAF) Mandatory Program. o. Disbursement – An outlay, including the issuance of cash, a check or electronic funds transfer (EFT). p. Division ﬁnance officer – The person who has been delegated by their division commissioner or chief with full responsibility of its ﬁnancial plan, including overseeing funds control and managing all phases of the cycle. See also ﬁnancial plan manager. q. Expenditure – A receipt of goods or services, usually accompanied by issuance of cash, a check or an electronic funds transfer to liquidate a valid obligation. r. Financial plan manager – The person responsible for day-to-day opera- tions of monitoring and controlling a ﬁnancial plan’s funds in the phase of the budget cycle. s. Fiscal year – The federal government’s accounting period, which begins on October
and ends on September

, and is designated by the dar year in which it ends. t. Forecast of revenue – The accounting transaction process under which Corporate Budget establishes funding in IFS based on the full cost of a signed reimbursable agreement and then sub-allocates budget authority a business unit under by transferring funds via a budget transaction to al- low reimbursable costs to be incurred for work performed under the terms of the reimbursable agreement. u. Fixed-fee Agreement – An agreement wherein the products and/or ser- vices may be provided once or multiple times; however, the full amount earnings is recognized the ﬁrst time a product is delivered and/or a is rendered. Fixed fees are also known as lump-sum or one-time payments. v. Full-time equivalent (FTE) – The basic measure of the employment used in the budget. It is the total number of regular, straight-time hours (that is, not including overtime or holiday hours) worked by employees di- vided by the number of compensable hours applicable to each ﬁscal Annual leave, sick leave, compensatory time off and other approved categories are considered hours worked for purposes of deﬁning full-time equivalent employment. w. Functional area – A data element in IFS that represents an activity, as Submission Processing. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
K

days to a full ﬁscal year. When the IRS is under a CR, Corporate Budget publishes special CR operating procedures on the Corporate Budget web-
Operating Guidelines 1.33.3

revolving funds, custodial funds and direct or reimbursable appropriations. In IFS, the fund ﬁeld indicates the appropriation. y. Fund center – A subdivision of a ﬁnancial plan in IFS representing an or- ganization’s areas of funds management responsibility. z. Funded program – The specialized accounting code assigned to each reimbursable project (e.g., RA
). This is a required ﬁeld when en- tering data in IFS. “Funded Program” was previously called “Internal Code”. aa. FEMA Form
Mission Assignment – The standard form used Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) for the emergency or major disaster number assigned for funding the event. ab. Form

, Reimbursable Agreement – Non-Federal Entities – Federal entities include state, local, and foreign governments and non- governmental entities. This form is the standard template and communication tool between the buyer and seller and enables the two agree on data elements and terms of the reimbursable transaction business begins. ac. Form
A and Form
B Interagency Agreement (IAA) - Form
A, IAA General Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section, and Form

B, IAA Order Requirements and Funding Information (Order) Sec- tion, are the required trading partner agreements for federal agreements. Federal agreements include all agreements with other sury bureaus or other federal agencies. This form is the standard tem- plate and communication tool between the buyer and seller and enables the two to agree on data elements and terms of the reimbursable trans- action before business begins. The standard IAA has two sections: Gen- eral Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section (Form
A) and Order Requirements and Funding Information (Order) Section (Form
B). Each standard IAA with a federal customer, must have exactly one and at least one

B, unless otherwise speciﬁed by the servicewide reimbursables team. ad. Integrated Financial System (IFS) – The administrative accounting tem used by the IRS. All reimbursable transactions, such as forecast of revenue and reimbursable earnings must be recorded in IFS. ae. Interagency agreement (IAA) – An interagency arrangement in which the IRS pays another agency for work performed or goods or services provided. af. Internal order code (IOC) – A data element in IFS that collects expendi- ture data for funded programs, formerly called internal orders. IOCs are used to monitor costs and, in some instances, revenues of internal jobs and/or tasks. Specialized accounting codes are assigned to each reim- bursable project. This is a required ﬁeld when entering data in IFS. Example: RA
, RA
VA, RA
“Internal Order Code” is now called “Funded Program.” ag. Intragovernmental Payment and Collection System (IPAC) – IPAC is an internet-based application that allows for the intragovernmental trans-

“Internal Order Code” is now called “Funded Program.” Intragovernmental Payment and Collection System (IPAC) – IPAC is an internet-based application that allows for the intragovernmental trans- fer of funds with descriptive data from one agency to another. The Gov- ernment Payables Section records IPAC disbursements and collections into the IPAC system, where funds are automatically transferred from one agency’s disbursement account to another agency’s collection account. Object class (OC) – Classiﬁcation of expense according to type as pre- scribed by OMB Circular A-
, Preparation, Submission and Execution of
1.33 Strategic Planning, Budgeting and Performance Management Process
the Budget; such as personal services, travel and equipment. this was a two-digit code (for example, OC
and OC
); however, OMBOC is now a more detailed three-digit code (for example, OCs

). See also, commitment item. ai. Obligation – A binding agreement that will result in outlays, immediately or in the future. Budgetary resources must be available before can legally be incurred. aj. Order – Identiﬁes the speciﬁc requesting agency requirements for of goods and/or services by the servicing agency. ak. Parked document – The transaction used by the BORC to park an direct fund cost transfer to the reimbursable fund (FV

-BZ) for later posting by Government Payables and Funds Management. This type of tandem transaction requires each of two separate offices to complete its respective side of the transaction. The BORC parks the transaction ing it available for Government Payables and Funds Management to act upon. Government Payables Section accesses the transaction, reviews for accuracy, and approves the transaction by posting the document. al. Recurring agreement – An agreement that will be renewed on an or other basis, unless a notice to discontinue is received. These agree- ments still require certain documents to be signed annually. am. Reimbursable agreement – The signed agreement between the IRS and buyer that sets out the terms and conditions under which reimburs- able work will be performed. Reimbursable agreements are typically penditure transfer payments. The paying account reports the and outlays. The receiving account reports the offsetting collections. purposes of this IRM, the term reimbursable means that the IRS is the seller or performing agency (not the buyer of services or the requesting agency). an. Reimbursable authority – The amount of reimbursable resources ap- proved and available to the
S to spend. Standard Form (SF)-
, Ap- portionment and Reapportionment Schedule, is used to set and/or reimbursable budget authority. ao. Reimbursable earnings – A category that appears on the SF-
, Ap- portionment and Reapportionment Schedule, and the SF-
, Report Budget Execution and Budgetary Resources. Reimbursable earnings recorded in IFS after reimbursable work has been performed and based on the actual cost of the work performed using an FV

-BZ transaction. ap. Reimbursable obligation – An obligation ﬁnanced by offsetting collec- tions credited to an expenditure account in payment for goods and ser- vices provided by that account. aq. Seller – The general term used for a trading partner that is providing goods and/or services. The seller is also the servicing agency. For all imbursable agreements discussed in this policy, the IRS is the seller. ar. Servicewide reimbursables team – The individual or individuals desig- nated by the director, Budget Execution, to ensure at the staff level that the reimbursable responsibilities of the ACFO, Corporate Budget, are ried out. as. Taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN) – An identiﬁcation number used by the IRS in the administration of tax laws. It is either a Social Security Number (SSN) or a unique nine-digit number issued by the IRS. The number for the IRS on Form
A, IAA General Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section; and Form
B, IAA Order Requirements and Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
K
Operating Guidelines 1.33.3
Information (Order) Section; and Form
, Agreement Covering bursable Services With Non-Federal Entities, is

at. Trading partners – The buyer and seller (federal agreements) are tively known as the “trading partners.” For a current listing of vendors trading partners, see the Financial Management website. au. Trading partner code – The Treasury Department attribute code used identify the federal trading partner agency. av. Treasury Account Symbol (TAS) – An identiﬁcation code assigned by the Department of the Treasury, in collaboration with the Office of Man- agement and Budget and the owner agency, to an individual appropria- tion, receipt, or other fund account. These accounts are deﬁned in TFM Volume I, Part
, Chapter

Operating Guidelines 1.33.3

) Reimbursements are budgetary resources that are subject to apportionment and are bound by the requirements and restrictions placed on appropriated funds. To administer properly and ensure effective funds control of the reim- bursable program, certain safeguards are incorporated in the IRS administrative funds control procedures and inter/intragovernmental agree- ments for goods and/or services. If funding and reimbursement requirements are prescribed by law and are inconsistent with IRS guidance, legal require- ments take precedence. (
) Like basic operating appropriations, expenditures against reimbursable authority or availability are always limited to the lesser of the approved tionment or the budgetary resources available. (

) Business units should institute procedures for administering the agreements, including the following requirements: a. Ensure that the estimated cost of goods and/or services and delivery date are not exceeded. b. Coordinate and administer the agreement within approved terms and conditions when more than one business unit is involved. c. Ensure prompt billing according to agreement terms. (
) Before the start of the ﬁscal year, Corporate Budget submits a SF-
, tionment and Reapportionment Schedule, to OMB to request an initial apportionment for the reimbursable budget for the following ﬁscal year. (

) After OMB approval, Corporate Budget assigns the reimbursable budget in IFS from the appropriations level to the apportionment level and then to the authorization level for earnings to be posted against. (
) If business units indicate via revised Form
A, IAA General Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section and Form
B, IAA Order Requirements and Funding Information (Order) Section; or Form
, Agreement Covering imbursable Services With Non-Federal Entities; or FEMA Form

, Mission Assignments, or that more funds are needed than are available in apportionment, Corporate Budget will request an increased apportionment OMB. This process can take weeks to complete, so business units are to notify Corporate Budget promptly of any signiﬁcant increases to their bursable funding needs. (

) Corporate Budget will request reimbursable estimates from business units before the start of the ﬁscal year. These estimates must provide adequate imbursable funding to support reimbursable operations during the upcoming ﬁscal year. (

) Monitoring and analyzing reimbursable earnings against reimbursable is critical to knowing whether payments are occurring accurately and timely. Authority BORCs must monitor individual projects based on the billing frequency set in the agreement. Consistently monitoring progress toward a
% earnings collection ensures proper oversight of reimbursable expenditures for each project. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

Corporate Budget will request reimbursable estimates from business units before the start of the ﬁscal year. These estimates must provide adequate re
imbursable funding to support reimbursable operations during the upcoming ﬁscal year.

Monitoring and analyzing reimbursable earnings against reimbursable authority is critical to knowing whether payments are occurring accurately and timely. BORCs must monitor individual projects based on the billing frequency set up in the agreement. Consistently monitoring progress toward a
% earnings collection ensures proper oversight of reimbursable expenditures for each project.

) BORCs should also perform quarterly tracking of all project earnings to whether intervention is needed to address earnings postings that fall below projections. (

) RPCs should renegotiate any projects that are expected to exceed projections. If earnings are signiﬁcantly lower than originally projected, IFS jections must be reduced but it is not necessary to renegotiate the (
) Any administrative modiﬁcation, such as accounting code changes or tions, should be addressed promptly to ensure accurate earnings are IFS. (
) Government Payables Section issues standard billings according to the agreement billing frequency and may contact business units if earnings fall behind schedule. (
) Year-end earnings must reach
% by the date established in the close guidelines. See IRM
, Administrative Accounting, Annual Close Guidelines. (

) The type of buyer, kind of agreement, and funding arrangements affect the level of detail in the agreement terms and conditions, the billing and method, and the accounting system transactions. See IRM
, Arrangements, and IRM
, Types of Agreements. These sections provide additional guidance on determining what type of agreement to and completing agreement forms. (
) Reimbursable agreements must cover only a single ﬁscal year unless multi- year funds are available from the buyer. When multi-year funds are from the buyer, a single Form
A, IAA General Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section, may be signed to match the term of the multi-year fund, new Form

B, IAA Order Requirements and Funding Information (Order) Section, must be signed every year. In addition, some Direct-Charge Reim- bursable Fund Agreement obligations can be initiated in the funding year extend past September
Any exceptions must have the approval of CB FR. (

) There are several types of funding arrangements depending on statutory authority that inﬂuence the need to provide goods and/or services. A, IAA General Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section, and Form
B, IAA Order quirements and Funding Information (Order) Section (federal), or Form

, Agreement Covering Reimbursable Services With Non-Federal Entities (non-federal). b. Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is an agreement between agencies or organizations that may be used in conjunction with Form
A, IAA General Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section, and Form

B, IAA Order Require- ments and Funding Information (Order) Section. No-Funds Interagency Agreement is an agreement between federal agencies for the mutual beneﬁt of the participating agencies. Each agency absorbs its own costs on a non-reimbursable basis. The combi- nation of an MOU and Form

Information (Order) Section, may also be used for no-funds There are two types of reimbursable agreements: • Federal government. • Nongovernment and state, local, and foreign governments. Each type of agreement is accounted for separately in IFS under one of distinct U.S. Standard General Ledger Accounts. Reimbursable agreements with other federal agencies (including Treasury) Form
A, IAA General Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section, and Form

, tion, Agreement and Certiﬁcation of Training, may be used in place of the

B, IAA Order Requirements and Funding Information (Order) Section if Servicewide Reimbursable Team approves. Federal government agreements are normally processed as interagency ments and must be in conformance with Intragovernmental Business Rules. Federal customers are billed monthly after the work has been completed unless speciﬁcally approved by Financial Reporting. Reimbursable agreements with non–federal entities use Form
, Agreement Covering Reimbursable Services With Non-Federal Entities and require the same critical elements contained in Form
A, IAA General Terms and Conditions (GT&C) Section and Form

B, IAA Order ments and Funding Information (Order) Section. Advance payments are required for agreements with state, local, and governments, commercial organizations, and private businesses because accounting systems do not interface with the federal government’s systems. For non-federal customers, billing must be a one-time payment unless cally approved by Financial Reporting.
Federal government agreements are normally processed as interagency agree- ments and must be in conformance with Intragovernmental Business Rules.

) This process is documented in the Reimbursables Standard Operating dures available from the Servicewide Reimbursables Team. (
) All business units executing reimbursable agreements or Memoranda of Un- derstanding (MOU) with federal agencies, states, and other external and stakeholders must comply with
, Delegations of Authority for tion, Finance and Management Activities. (

) If the MOU, implementing agreement, or other agreement allows for the exchange of a taxpayer return or taxpayer return information, the document must be coordinated with the director, Privacy, Governmental Liaison and closure before the delegated authority may execute the agreement. (
) Cost assignment methods must be consistent with the Federal Accounting Standards Advisory Board (FASAB) accounting standards. (
) One of the ﬁve standards for federal managerial cost accounting, as stated SFFAS No.

, is “determining the full costs of government goods and/or services.” The full cost of an output is the total amount of resources used to produce the output. This includes direct and indirect costs that contribute to output, regardless of funding sources. The full cost of an output produced by business unit is the sum of: a. The cost of resources consumed by the business unit that directly or rectly contribute to the output. b. The cost of identiﬁable support services provided by sustaining IRS business units. (

) When reimbursable projects use the same types of goods and/or services as direct-funded projects, the reimbursable project costs will use the same rates and consumption basis as the direct-funded projects. (

) Recognition of Earned Reimbursements: In accordance with the SFFAS No. Accounting for Revenue and Other Financing Sources and Concepts for onciling Budgetary and Financial Accounting, “earned“ or “exchanged” revenues are created once the seller provides goods and/or services to the buyer for the amount negotiated in the agreement - meaning that the or revenue should not be recognized until costs are incurred from providing goods and services. (

) Direct costs are costs that can be speciﬁcally identiﬁed with a single program area, activity, product or service. Typical direct costs for the IRS include: a. Salaries, beneﬁts, and other employee compensation directly related to the work being performed under the reimbursable agreement. b. Accrued annual leave and compensatory time. c. Materials and supplies. d. Travel and relocation costs. e. Contractual services.
This process is documented in the Reimbursables Standard Operating Proce- dures available from the Servicewide Reimbursables Team.
a. The cost of resources consumed by the business unit that directly or rectly contribute to the output. b. The cost of identiﬁable support services provided by sustaining IRS business units.
Direct costs are costs that can be speciﬁcally identiﬁed with a single area, activity, product or service. Typical direct costs for the IRS include:

a. Salaries, beneﬁts, and other employee compensation directly related to the work being performed under the reimbursable agreement. b. Accrued annual leave and compensatory time. c. Materials and supplies. d. Travel and relocation costs. e. Contractual services.
Guidelines

f. Any other costs that are directly attributable to the work outlined in reimbursable agreement. Indirect costs are the costs of resources that are jointly or commonly consumed by two or more business units’ activities but are not speciﬁcally identiﬁable to a single product or service. For the purpose of reimbursable agreements, indirect costs include sustaining business unit labor costs that support the IRS as a whole. As of the date of publication, sustaining units include CFO, C&L, FMSS, HCO, IT, PGLD and the business units costs funded within the NHQM and

ﬁnancial plans. Other-than-full overhead rates that deviate from the standard reduction on the overhead worksheet and that are not related to reimbursable exemptions must be reviewed and signed by the director, Budget Examples of services where there may be indirect costs include: a. General management and administrative services of sustaining tions b. Facilities management and ground maintenance services (security, utilities, and building maintenance) c. Procurement and contracting services d. Financial management and accounting services e. Information technology services f. Services to acquire and operate property, plant, and equipment g. Publication, reproduction, graphics and video services h. Research, analytical, and statistical services i. Human resources and personnel services j. Library and legal services Indirect costs can be incurred within a business unit as a result of its own tivities or when the business unit receives products or services generated other business units. The business unit’s indirect costs are assigned in accordance with cost allocation methodologies outlined in IRM Cost Allocation Methodologies. Most indirect costs accumulate within identiﬁable business units. However, some costs such as depreciation and facilities costs cannot be linked to identiﬁable business unit. In those instances, such costs are allocated on cost allocation methodologies. Determining the cost estimate of a reimbursable agreement requires the ﬁcation of the projected full cost of the products and services that are to provided to the buyer. Each reimbursable project is unique and cost estimate can vary based on the requirements of the project. The FASAB, SFFAS No.
, Managerial Cost Accounting Concepts and dards for the Federal Government, issued July
, establishes internal ing standards to accurately measure and manage the cost of federal SFFAS No.
provides an order of preference framework for cost The cost assignment process links accumulated costs with cost objects in ciﬁc reporting periods. There are three methods of cost assignment:

Strategic Planning, Budgeting and Management Process a. Trace costs directly wherever feasible and economically practicable. b. Assign costs on a cause-and-effect basis. c. Allocate costs on a reasonable and consistent basis. (

) These methods should be used by RPCs to develop full-cost projections for the cost of the products and/or services provided by reimbursable project(s). This includes labor, non-labor, and overhead costs. (

) The RPC must calculate direct labor and non-labor costs using a that conforms to the guidance outlined above. a. The RPC must provide the direct cost methodology to the Corporate Budget Reimbursables Team for review and signature. b. If direct costs are based on a sound methodology, there is no required format for presenting the direct cost methodology. See Corporate website for the direct and indirect cost templates. c. Rolling over cost estimates from the previous year is not an acceptable methodology. Cost estimates must be updated every time a new agree- ment is negotiated. (

) To determine the appropriate overhead rate for each project annually, reim- bursable project owners must use the overhead worksheet developed by Corporate Budget. This worksheet includes standard overhead rates for each category of overhead and allows the RPC to exempt certain categories of overhead that are not applicable to a speciﬁc agreement. a. There are separate rates and separate overhead worksheets for direct/ support business units and for sustaining business units. This is the overhead methodology for direct/support business units includes all labor performed by sustaining business units as overhead, while the methodology for sustaining business units logically does not. b. Direct/support business units include Appeals, Counsel, Criminal Investi- gation, Large Business & International, Small Business/Self-Employed, Tax Exempt & Government Entities, Taxpayer Advocate Service, and Wage & Investment. c. All business units not listed above are sustaining business units. (

) To complete the reimbursable overhead worksheet, the RPC should be aware of the following: a. The worksheet includes percentage rates for each category of overhead costs. b. Labor overhead costs capture salary and beneﬁt costs of sustaining business units. Because all IRS employees beneﬁt from the services provided by these organizations, labor overhead costs cannot be exempted without approval from the director, Budget Execution. Such exceptions will be rare and require an explanation. c. Non-labor overhead costs are those speciﬁc services provided to IRS employees. If some of these non-labor services are not provided to support the speciﬁc reimbursable work, then they may be exempted. For any non-labor cost that is exempted, an explanation must be provided. d. If non-labor costs needed to support the agreement are known, they should be calculated as direct costs and excluded from the overhead cost calculation.

) All overhead earnings will be posted to a speciﬁc accounting string by Corporate Budget and disseminated by the Servicewide Reimbursables Team. (

) Cost increases that occur during the performance of the agreement must be recovered, unless the Servicewide Reimbursable Team determines be immaterial - meaning that the administrative cost of collecting the is more than the amount of the increase. (

) When an employee is detailed to another government agency, the ity for recommending, approving and managing the accounting of his or award rests with the seller, regardless of the type of award. This policy is intended to prevent the duplication of employee awards by both the seller buyer sides of the reimbursable agreement. (
) The best time to discuss the award budget and method of conveying the formance evaluation results and award is during the agreement negotiation process. (

) This section provides the processing requirements and IFS document tions needed to complete reimbursable business. Reimbursable earnings Accounting be collected under a non-advance agreement or an agreement paid in advance. (

) From the initial budget estimates worksheet, to the ﬁnal earnings and closeout of the reimbursable project, the budget and accounting tions conform to one of two collection methods: advance payments or non- advance Intragovernmental Payment and Collection System (IPAC) (

Strategic Planning, Budgeting and Performance Management Process

Monthly billing is the preferred frequency for all agreements. For these agreements, actual costs should be captured monthly to reﬂect the work that has occurred during that month. It is not appropriate to simply divide the annual cost into equal monthly payments unless the cost of the work performed is consistent from month to month. Advance payments are used for non-federal customers. They are most often one-time payments with opportunities for upward/downward adjust- ments as the project nears completion. Non-advance payments are used for federal customers. They are collected using the IPAC process and follow a pre-set billing frequency (for example, monthly, quarterly, lump-sum). Most opportunities for upward/downward adjustments to non-advance reimbursables occur during the fourth quarter of the ﬁscal year. The processing step for these collection methods is found in IRM
, Indirect/Overhead Costs.

) The validity of reimbursable collections data reported in the central and published in the federal government’s ﬁnancial reports depends upon accuracy of the monthly statements of transactions submitted by all ments and agencies. The timeliness of reports depends on strict with BFS-assigned deadlines and the IRS monthly billing and collection tables. (

) Adhering to the monthly reporting cycle is a critical element in maintaining internal accounting controls. The IRS processes transactions according to formal IFS posting models. The posting models require certain related to the monthly processing cycle be completed within the same (

) Late entries or those posted outside of the monthly cycle cause relationships to become out-of-balance. Correcting an account requires Financial Reporting to reconcile and complete adjustments IRS ﬁnancial statements can be forwarded to BFS. (

) Most reimbursable earnings are considered offsetting collections that identiﬁed with IRS apportioned reimbursable authority. Reimbursable are initially recorded against the direct fund appropriation codes ending “D.” These expenses must be transferred to the reimbursable fund string ending with an “R.” The purpose of the schedule of reimbursable

) IFS earnings posted against an erroneous buyer number must be reversed. Line items with an erroneous buyer number must be deleted on the forecast revenue document (FMV
). This involves closing or “setting to complete” the erroneous accounting line and creating a new accounting line for processing future transactions. (
) The instructions for completing an FV
can be found on the Financial Man- agement website. (

) Government Payables prefers electronic submission of reimbursable accounting transactions, justiﬁcations, and documentation. However, hard copies are also acceptable if necessary. Reimbursable earnings (BZ earnings) documents should be forwarded this electronic mailbox: *CFO BFC DCU Reimbursable Program. b. EV and OC documents should be forwarded to this electronic mailbox: *CFO BFC Electronic EV. (

Government Payables assigns speciﬁc staff to each business unit’s able projects. The reimbursable project inventory and contacts list are on the Financial Management website. A complete list of all ﬁnancial codes can be found in the Financial ment Codes Handbook, which is revised quarterly and available from Corporate Budget on its website. A funded program code is referenced on each agreement and is a element. The funded program code is a unique,

-character, code. A funded program (internal order) code must be established before able documents can be processed in IFS. Corporate Budget, in conjunction with the business units, determines funded program codes will be rolled over for a new ﬁscal year and codes need to be established during the course of the ﬁscal year.
A funded program code is referenced on each agreement and is a critical data element. The funded program code is a unique, 9-character, alphanumeric

) In instances where there has been an overpayment of invoices or where advance payments exceed needs, contact Government Payables Section guidance regarding refunds. (
) Business units closing out reimbursable agreements at the end of the ﬁscal year must comply with IRM
, Administrative Accounting, Annual Closeout Guidelines, which assists business units with facilitating and monitoring year-end close activities. (

) The following IFS reports support reimbursables monitoring and analysis: a. Status of funds report: ZSOF_ECC to check reimbursable fund Reports with project accounting line details. b. Earmarked funds journal: S_P
displays reimbursable projects for posted earnings and open balances. c. Reimbursable audit report: ZOFR
provides a summary of project customer and general ledger account. d. BW
SOAF reports provides historical FTE and budget statuses ﬁscal year periods and various sorting options.
OMB Circular A-11 provides guidance on managing prior-year reimbursable agreements. See Circular A-11, Section 20, Terms and Concepts.
